content.title: High-Flow Nasal Cannula
content.summary: High-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) delivers heated, humidified oxygen at flows up to 60 L/min, providing oxygen support, modest PEEP effect, dead space washout, and improved patient comfort for hypoxemic respiratory failure.
key_points: Delivers heated (37°C), humidified oxygen at flows 30-60 L/min via nasal prongs
Provides ~1 cm H2O PEEP per 10 L/min flow; up to 5-6 cm H2O at 60 L/min
FLORALI trial: reduced intubation in hypoxemic respiratory failure vs standard O2 or NIV
Dead space washout improves ventilation efficiency; reduces rebreathing of CO2
Better tolerated than NIV for many patients; allows eating, speaking, oral care
Monitor for failure: ROX index (SpO2/FiO2 ÷ RR) <3.85 at 12h predicts intubation need
content.statement: High-flow nasal cannula is a respiratory support modality delivering heated, humidified oxygen at flows up to 60 L/min through wide-bore nasal prongs, providing physiologic benefits including precise FiO2 delivery, positive airway pressure, nasopharyngeal dead space washout, and improved mucociliary function for patients with hypoxemic respiratory failure.

explanation.intuition: Traditional nasal cannula delivers dry, cool oxygen at low flows that mix with room air, making actual FiO2 unpredictable. HFNC delivers much higher flows of warm, humidified gas that matches or exceeds the patient's inspiratory demand, ensuring they're actually breathing the prescribed FiO2 and creating a gentle positive pressure in the airways.
explanation.key_insight: HFNC sits in the therapeutic space between standard oxygen and NIV/mechanical ventilation. It's often better tolerated than a mask while providing more support than standard cannula. The key is recognizing when it's enough and when patients need escalation - the ROX index helps predict who will fail.
explanation.technical_details: HFNC uses heated humidifier and specialized wide-bore nasal cannula to deliver 30-60 L/min of blended air/oxygen at 37°C and 100% relative humidity. High flow generates positive pressure in the nasopharynx (~1 cm H2O per 10 L/min with mouth closed). Dead space washout reduces CO2 rebreathing. Precise FiO2 delivery (21-100%) because flow exceeds peak inspiratory demand.

definitions_glossary.high_flow_nasal_cannula: Respiratory support device delivering heated humidified oxygen at 30-60 L/min via nasal prongs
definitions_glossary.heated_humidification: Gas conditioning to 37°C and 100% relative humidity for airway comfort and function
definitions_glossary.dead_space_washout: Flushing of nasopharyngeal cavity reducing CO2 rebreathing and improving ventilation efficiency
definitions_glossary.positive_airway_pressure: Low level PEEP effect from high gas flow; approximately 1 cm H2O per 10 L/min
definitions_glossary.fio2_delivery: Precise inspired oxygen fraction because flow exceeds patient inspiratory demand
definitions_glossary.rox_index: Ratio of SpO2/FiO2 to respiratory rate; predicts HFNC success vs failure
definitions_glossary.respiratory_failure: Inability to maintain adequate gas exchange; HFNC indicated for hypoxemic (Type 1) failure
definitions_glossary.nasal_prongs: Wide-bore nasal cannula designed for high flow rates
definitions_glossary.inspiratory_demand: Patient peak inspiratory flow; typically 30-60 L/min in distress
definitions_glossary.mucociliary_function: Airway clearance mechanism improved by heated humidification
definitions_glossary.patient_comfort: Major advantage of HFNC - better tolerated than masks; allows eating and talking
definitions_glossary.escalation_criteria: Signs of HFNC failure requiring progression to NIV or intubation

mechanism_of_benefit.fio2_matching: Flow matches peak inspiratory demand ensuring actual FiO2 equals set FiO2
mechanism_of_benefit.peep_effect: Positive nasopharyngeal pressure recruits alveoli; ~5-6 cm H2O at 60 L/min
mechanism_of_benefit.dead_space_washout: High flow flushes anatomic dead space reducing CO2 rebreathing
mechanism_of_benefit.humidification: Warm humidified gas maintains mucociliary function and patient comfort

advantages_over_standard_o2.consistent_fio2: Standard cannula mixes with room air; HFNC delivers prescribed FiO2
advantages_over_standard_o2.peep: No PEEP with standard O2; modest PEEP with HFNC
advantages_over_standard_o2.comfort: Heated humidified gas is more comfortable than dry oxygen

strong_evidence.hypoxemic_respiratory_failure: FLORALI trial showed reduced intubation vs standard O2 or NIV in de novo hypoxemia
strong_evidence.pre_oxygenation: For intubation; maintains oxygenation during apneic period

moderate_evidence.covid_19: Widely used; allows prone positioning while on HFNC
moderate_evidence.immunocompromised: May delay or avoid intubation in select patients
moderate_evidence.procedural_sedation: Maintains oxygenation during bronchoscopy, GI procedures

uncertain_evidence.hypercapnic_failure: NIV is preferred for COPD exacerbation; HFNC role unclear
uncertain_evidence.cardiogenic_edema: NIV/CPAP is standard; HFNC provides less pressure support

initial_settings.flow: Start 30-40 L/min; can increase to 60 L/min
initial_settings.fio2: Titrate to SpO2 >92% (or target per condition)
initial_settings.temperature: 37°C is standard; can reduce if patient uncomfortable

titration.flow: Increase for work of breathing; higher flow = more PEEP and dead space washout
titration.tolerance: Reduce flow or temperature if patient uncomfortable

monitoring.clinical: Respiratory rate, work of breathing, mental status, comfort
monitoring.oxygenation: SpO2, consider ABG if not improving
monitoring.rox_index: Calculate ROX = (SpO2/FiO2)/RR; <3.85 at 12h predicts need for intubation

clinical_signs: Accessory muscle use despite maximal settings

rox_index_prediction.interpretation: ROX <2.85 at 2h, <3.47 at 6h, or <3.85 at 12h predicts failure
rox_index_prediction.action: Low ROX should prompt consideration of NIV or intubation

skos.definition: Respiratory support delivering heated, humidified oxygen at high flows (30-60 L/min) via nasal prongs, providing precise FiO2, modest PEEP effect, and dead space washout for hypoxemic respiratory failure.

icd10_pcs.display: Administration of oxygen via nasal cannula

learning_objectives: Describe the physiologic mechanisms of high-flow nasal cannula
Identify appropriate indications for HFNC use
Apply initial settings and titration of HFNC
Calculate and interpret the ROX index
Recognize signs of HFNC failure requiring escalation
Compare HFNC with NIV and standard oxygen therapy
clinical_pearls: HFNC provides ~1 cm H2O PEEP per 10 L/min - at 60 L/min that's ~5-6 cm H2O
ROX index helps predict failure - calculate SpO2/FiO2 divided by respiratory rate
Patients who keep their mouth open get less PEEP effect from HFNC
Better tolerated than NIV - patients can eat, drink, and talk
Don't delay intubation if HFNC is failing - ROX trending down is a warning sign
HFNC is great for pre-oxygenation before intubation - apneic oxygenation during laryngoscopy

board_yield.usmle_step1: Physiology of dead space, gas mixing, airway pressure
board_yield.usmle_step2: Indications, settings, FLORALI trial, ROX index
board_yield.abim_critical_care: Evidence base, comparison to NIV, specific populations

common_misconceptions: Misconception: HFNC is just high-flow oxygen. Reality: It provides PEEP, dead space washout, and precise FiO2 - more than just oxygen
Misconception: HFNC is equivalent to NIV. Reality: HFNC provides less pressure support; NIV preferred for hypercapnic failure
Misconception: Higher flow is always better. Reality: Titrate to effect and patient comfort

citations.reference: Frat JP, et al. High-flow oxygen through nasal cannula in acute hypoxemic respiratory failure (FLORALI). N Engl J Med. 2015;372(23):2185-2196.

evidence.confidence_rationale: Strong RCT evidence from FLORALI trial and subsequent studies

sources.source: FLORALI Trial. N Engl J Med. 2015;372:2185-2196
sources.relevance: Landmark trial establishing HFNC in hypoxemic respiratory failure
